Definition.Document:
Transformer Replacement Strategy using True Age Calculation

Outcome:

  • Reduces CapEx by prioritizing replacement based on actual equipment condition
  • Improve system reliability to avoid $10's of millions in unplanned downtime and CapEx and premature replacement

Challenge:

Most transformer manufacturers define the end of life as age 40, however ligher or more eavily loaded transformers can easily deviate from this value leading to unexpoected outages or replacement of transformers that still have substantail usable life left. 

Solution:

Starting Point

Calculate Hot Spot and Aging Factor

Calculate the hourly average power 
(Do it! Use Signal From Condition to create an hourly discrete average of the 3 PH MVA)

Using the hourly average power, we can find the RMS load on a 24 hour basis, which is used to calculate the Winding Hottest Spot Temp

Using an IEEE formula (shown below), we can calculate a Transformer aging factor

Visualize 

Use the XY Plot to visualize how hot spot temperature correlates with load or show Time Aged v Elapsed in a Table

Scale Across Assets

In a table, we can show the time aged for this transformer and scale out across assets 
(Do It - scale this table across all assets at this substation using the asset button! This table can then be filtered to show only at risk assets.)

In Trend View, we can find periods when a high aging rate was present 
(Do It! Use value search to find whenever the time aged was over X )

We can monitor the entire tranformer fleet for a high aging rate using Treemap 
(Do It! Change to Treemap View, color the High Aging Rate red, and explore the entire asset tree)
